natural problem: Find the smallest two-digit prime number such that reversing the digits of the number produces a composite number.
natural solution: We begin by listing the two-digit primes with 1 as the tens digit: 11, 13, 17, 19.
When reversed, the above numbers are 11, 31, 71, and 91. The first three are prime, but 91 is composite (7 times 13), as desired.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "p >= 10"
and h2 : "p < 100"
and h3 : "\<not> prime (rev_digits p)"
shows  "p = 19"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest two-digit prime number such that reversing the digits of the number produces a composite number. The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We begin by listing the two-digit primes with 1 as the tens digit: 11, 13, 17, 19.
 When reversed, the above numbers are 11, 31, 71, and 91. The first three are prime, but 91 is composite (7 times 13), as desired.
 Hence, our desired prime is $\boxed{19}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "p >= 10"
and h2 : "p < 100"
and h3 : "\<not> prime (rev_digits p)"
shows  "p = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find a prime number between 10 and 100 such that when the digits of the number are reversed, the resulting number is not prime. The final answer is 19.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime composite reverse :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. prime n \<longrightarrow> n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. composite n \<longrightarrow> n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. reverse n = n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. prime n \<longrightarrow> composite (reverse n)"
shows  "\<exists>n. prime n \<and> n = 19"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the smallest two-digit prime number such that reversing the digits of the number produces a composite number. The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We begin by listing the two-digit primes with 1 as the tens digit: 11, 13, 17, 19.
 When reversed, the above numbers are 11, 31, 71, and 91. The first three are prime, but 91 is composite (7 times 13), as desired.
 Hence, our desired prime is $\boxed{19}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime composite reverse :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. prime n \<longrightarrow> n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. composite n \<longrightarrow> n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. reverse n = n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. prime n \<longrightarrow> composite (reverse n)"
shows  "\<exists>n. prime n \<and> n = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Is there a prime number between 10 and 100 such that when its digits are reversed, the resulting number is composite? The answer is yes, and that prime number is 19.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: int
assumes h0 : "prime x"
and h1 : "x >= 10"
and h2 : "~ prime (rev_digits x)"
shows  "x = 19"

where "rev_digits x = (x mod 10) * 10 + (x div 10)"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes n :: int and reverse :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and composite :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "n >= 10"
and h1 : "n < 100"
and h2 : "prime n"
and h3 : "composite (reverse n)"
and h4 : "\<forall> m. m >= 10 \<and> m < n \<and> prime m \<longrightarrow> \<not> composite (reverse m)"
shows  "n = 19"

a_5.formal problem:
Theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f x = reverse digits of x"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. prime x \<and> x \<ge> 10 \<and> x < 100 \<longrightarrow> \<not> prime (f x)"
shows  "LEAST x. x \<ge> 10 \<and> x < 100 \<and> prime x \<and> \<not> prime (f x) = 19"

a_8.formal problem:

fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> prime n \<and> \<not> prime (f n)"
and h1 : "f = (\<lambda>n. (n mod 10) * 10 + (n div 10))"
shows  "\<exists>!n. n = 19"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime n"
and h1 : "10 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 100"
and h3 : "\<not> prime (rev n)"
shows  "n = 19"
where "rev n = (n mod 10) * 10 + n div 10"
